title: 109_hr982
content: The "Expedited Rescissions Act of 2005" allows for quick consideration of proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Expedited Rescissions Act of 2005" permits the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriation Act within 3 days of enactment, with a draft bill specifying the amount to be rescinded. The "Expedited Rescissions Act of 2005" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment, with a separate message for each subcommittee's jurisdiction. The special message must specify the budget authority to be rescinded. The House of Representatives must introduce a draft bill accompanying a special message within three legislative days. If not introduced, any Member may introduce the bill. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision, and must be reported within seven legislative days. The bill must be reported by the Committee on Appropriations within seven legislative days. If not reported, the committee will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote in the House of Representatives within 10 legislative days. If passed, the bill will be transmitted to the Senate within one calendar day. A motion in the House of Representatives to consider a bill under this section is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. It is not in order to amend the motion, move to reconsider the vote, limit debate further, recommit the bill, or reconsider the vote on the bill. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding House Rules application can be made. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to the procedure for bills under this section without debate. A bill sent to the Senate must go to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report the bill within seven legislative days. If the committee fails to report the bill, it is automatically discharged. The Senate must vote on the bill within the 10th legislative day after receiving it. The Senate has specific rules for considering bills, including privileged motions and limited debate time. The majority and minority leaders control the debate time, with a maximum of 10 hours for bill discussion and 1 hour for motions or appeals. The Senate has rules for considering bills, with limited debate time controlled by the majority and minority leaders. Amendments to bills are prohibited, and motions to further limit debate or recommit a bill are not debatable. The Senate has rules for considering bills, with limited debate time controlled by the majority and minority leaders. Amendments to bills are prohibited, and motions to further limit debate or recommit a bill are not debatable. Representatives or the Senate cannot demand a division of the question. Motion to suspend subsection rules is not allowed. Rescinded budget authority must be made available for obligation after certain conditions are met. The bill allows rescissions to implement the President's special message. It includes definitions for "appropriation Act" and "legislative day." Rulemaking powers under Section 904 are amended, and conforming amendments are made to Section 1011 of the Act. Section 1011 of the Act is amended to update paragraph numbers and references. Section 1015 is also amended to reflect the changes in paragraph numbers and references. Section 1011 and 1015 of the Act are amended to update paragraph numbers and references. Section 1016 is also amended to include the insertion of "1014" in various subparagraphs. The table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act is amended to redesignate items relating to sections 1013 through 1017 as items relating to sections 1014 through 1018, and to insert a new item after section 1012. "Sec. 1013. Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions." Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 applies to budget authority provided by appropriation Acts enacted during the One Hundred Ninth Congress and thereafter. The President may propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of a new Congress if the previous Congress did not consider the proposed rescissions before adjourning. The President may propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of a new Congress if the previous Congress did not consider the proposed rescissions before adjourning. A draft bill must accompany a special message for rescissions, and if not introduced by the House leaders, any Member may introduce it on the third legislative day. The House and Senate will then consider the bill as outlined in section 1013.
